Award.AwardTitle: Development of a Multi-User Molecular Facility at Mote Marine Laboratory's Tropical Research Laboratory
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal requests funding to set up a multiuser general-purpose molecular laboratory to be used by in house staff, visiting scientists, students and educational groups at Motes Tropical Research Laboratory (TRL) located in the Florida Keys. The addition of molecular equipment to Motes Tropical Research Laboratory will support research across numerous cross disciplines within marine biology including coral genetics, microbiology, immunology, and biomedical research projects currently ongoing at Mote Marine Laboratory.

Broader Impacts

The TFL facility is used extensively especially by visiting scientists. In 2009, over 55 Universities, Colleges and/or Agencies have operated courses or workshops out of this facility. As part of MML's NSF funded REU program, students from underrepresented groups (Native Pacific Islanders) have participated in marine science research projects for the past eight years. Visiting scientists will be able to use the equipment at this southernmost marine lab in the continental US. The PIs have a policy in place for assuring access to outside users. Summer courses will use the equipment. Mote has intensive student internships. The PI Matz (from UT, A) ran a workshop in 2009 teaching qPCR analysis for marine biologists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have received funding to equip a molecular laboratory to be used by in house staff, visiting scientists, students and educational groups at Motes Tropical Research Laboratory (TRL) located on Summerland Key in the Florida Keys. Gaining the ability to perform molecular genetics techniques and analysis at this location enhances the scientific integrity of the field station and encourages new collaborations between Mote staff and visiting scientists. Our research team includes: a microbiologist with expertise in classical genetics specializing in coral reef health, disease and microbial community dynamics of marine microbes; an ecologist with expertise in population genetics; and a cell and molecular biologist studying molecular mechanisms and ecological roles of fluorescence and luminescence in marine organisms. Other collaborators/users include: visiting scientists and graduate students from locations across the globe; instructors for advanced molecular-based summer courses taught through the field lab; undergraduate students participating in Mote’s range of internship program opportunities, including the NSF Funded Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Program; and graduate students from collaborating universities.

Intellectual Merit: The addition of molecular equipment to Motes Tropical Research Laboratory aids in supporting research across numerous disciplines within marine biology including coral genetics, microbiology, immunology, and biomedical research projects currently ongoing at Mote Marine Laboratory. The requested improvements are currently being used for 1) genetic tracking of corals for restoration and management applications 2) symbiosis, bacterial diversity, dynamics and pathogen persistence in coral reef environments 3) microbial dynamics of red tide events 4) the development of molecular tools for prioritizing coral conservation efforts, and 5) ongoing molecular based summer courses offered through TRL. Up until now, all research accomplishments achieved for these projects have been realized through the use of similar instruments at our distant laboratory facility in Sarasota, FL or by transporting costly equipment to TRL during courses or long field seasons. The acquisition of the new molecular facility fills a tremendous void in our ability to carry out experiments efficiently and significantly enhances the infrastructure at the Tropical Research Laboratory by expanding our range of research goals and enabling advanced resources and training to staff, visiting scientists, and students.

Broader Impacts: As the Southernmost marine laboratory in the continental US, Mote’s Tropical Research Laboratory is a valuable resource for staff, visiting scientists and students studying various aspects of marine science. TRL is strategically located in the Lower Florida Keys with direct access to a variety of marine systems including Florida Bay, coral reef, sea grass, hard- bottom and mangrove habitats. The addition of a real time PCR system, PCR, centrifuges, electrophoresis equipment, gel documentation systems,  a -80 C freezer and all supporting supplies, greatly aids in providing a cross-disciplinary scientific resource for our community and visiting scientists that is not currently available in this location. Direct access to these instruments will greatly improve the quality and quantity of our research and education efforts and will increase the number of research opportunities available for staff, visiting scientists and students. Mote Marine Laboratory encourages the participation of underrepresented groups, such as women and minority students, in our marine science programs and NSF/REU programs.
